thread.title: This viral picture of a goalkeeper eating a pie isn't what it seems
thread.title_full: This viral picture of a goalkeeper eating a pie isn't what it seems

author: Gianluca Mezzofiore
title: This viral picture of a goalkeeper eating a pie isn't what it seems
text:
Wayne Shaw is a 23-stone (322-pound) reserve goalkeeper who became an internet hero after pictures of him eating a pie during his team Sutton United's FA cup game against Arsenal made the rounds on social media.
✅ Back-up keeper
✅ All three subs made
✅ Time for a pie
Tuck in, Wayne Shaw! #EmiratesFACup pic.twitter.com/gjQWLzugVx
— BT Sport Football (@btsportfootball) February 20, 2017
However, the hilariously cheeky stunt hides a more uncomfortable truth.
SEE ALSO: 14 times footballers were unintentionally hilarious on Twitter
As many people noticed on Twitter, Sun Bets, a betting company linked to The Sun newspaper, offered odds of 8-1 against him eating a pie on the bench during the game.
Name a more iconic duo, we'll wait...
Wayne Shaw To Eat A Pie Live On Air = 8/1 https://t.co/RbjPZpZ6NK #FACup #SUTARS pic.twitter.com/0YbfWbsHJh
— Sun Bets (@SunBets) February 20, 2017
Even worse, Shaw himself admitted in a post-match interview that he knew about the bet:
“A few of the lads said to me earlier on, ‘What is going on with the 8-1 about eating a pie?’ I said, ‘I don’t know, I’ve eaten nothing all day, so I might give it a go later on,’” he said.
“Sun Bets had us at 8-1 to eat a pie. I thought I would give them a bit of banter and let’s do it. All the subs were on and we were 2-0 down.”
The Football Association’s rules on betting say: “A participant shall not bet, either directly or indirectly, or instruct, permit, cause or enable any person to bet on (i) the result, progress, conduct or any other aspect of, or occurrence in, a football match or competition.”
Safe to say that after the initial, hilarious reaction, people on Twitter didn't really like that it was a PR stunt:
So about this goalie eating a pie. Turns out, the Sun were offering bets before the match on whether he'd do exactly this. https://t.co/lpGRjUAQHd
— Dai Lama (@WelshDalaiLama) February 20, 2017
@TeleFootball like his reserve goalkeeper taking backhanders from the sun for something they took bets on????
— marlon (@inthesmoke) February 21, 2017
Someone put up, that the pie eating in the #SuttonvArsenal #FACup match was an advertised bet and PR stunt by The Sun Bets.
— Gerry Bennison (@AlresfordBear) February 21, 2017
@TomBlargh FA Cup last night, non-league side had a fat goalie who ate a pie on the bench. The Sun happened to be taking bets on it.
— Ingobernable Dazzler (@DanTheDazzler) February 21, 2017
Sutton sold their soul to the sun today. The sun were also taking bets on the keeper to eat a pie during the game. And shock horror he did..
— Steve Elliott (@Teeto_Wxm) February 20, 2017
Turns out The Sun bets were offering odds on this happening. Massive publicity stunt.
— David (@davidlewissmart) February 20, 2017
It gets worse. Turns out the pie eating keeper is a promo pawn to get people to acknowledge 'The Sun Bets' is a thing. #dontbetwiththesun https://t.co/mUh33mQN8H
— oli moore (@ojmoore_) February 20, 2017
A non-league side taking sponsorship from The Sun and fixing spot bets on a "quirky keeper".
Uh huh. "Magic of the Cup".
Next.
— Brandon Boyer (@iBrandonBoyer) February 20, 2017
Oh dear. Sutton just went down in my estimation. That and the 'Sun Bets' sponsorship on the shirts. https://t.co/vsQUXPwqnD
— Pete Morgan (@MobyMooby) February 20, 2017
@FA the sun fixing bets. Is this not worth investigating? pic.twitter.com/7ihg5Yu2Ds
— Dave (@Irontoffee) February 20, 2017
Suttons Shirt sponsor The Sun Bets offered 8/1 on Shaw being on tv eating a pie. His efforts couldn't have been any more clear
— Dean S.W (@Deano4x8) February 20, 2017
Was definitely paid to do this haha as the Sun Bets had it as a special @ 8/1!! https://t.co/IGfTXyTc2C
— Stephen Bailey (@S_BaileyITFC) February 20, 2017
